content:
A 3-inch border will indeed create a beautiful frame around your quilt.

To calculate the fabric needed for the border, we'll need to calculate the perimeter of the quilt. Since you're making a 12x12 block quilt with 12 blocks, the finished quilt size will be:

12 blocks x 12 inches/block = 144 inches (across) x 144 inches (down)

To calculate the perimeter, we add up the lengths of all four sides:

Perimeter = 2 x (144 inches + 144 inches) = 576 inches

Since you want a 3-inch border, we'll add 6 inches (3 inches x 2) to the perimeter to account for the border width:

Total border length = 576 inches + 6 inches = 582 inches

To convert this to yards, we divide by 36 (since there are 36 inches in a yard):

Total border length (yards) = 582 inches ÷ 36 = 16.17 yards

Since you can't buy a fraction of a yard, we'll round up to the nearest quarter yard to ensure you have enough fabric. In this case, you'll need:

16.25 yards of fabric for the border

Adding this to your previous estimate for the remaining blocks, you'll need a total of:

4 yards (remaining blocks) + 16.25 yards (border) = 20.25 yards of fabric

So, to be safe, you should consider getting around 21-22 yards of fabric to account for any potential errors or variations in fabric usage. This will give you a comfortable buffer to work with.

Remember, it's always better to have a little extra fabric, rather than not enough!
